data.title: Women’s Rights and Western Imperialism in Iraq: Past Meets Present
data.meta_description: 'Women’s Rights and Western Imperialism in Iraq: Past Meets Present' published in 'The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism'
data.text:
Al-Ali, N. (2007). Iraqi women. Untold stories from 1948 to the present. London: ZedBooks.

Al-Ali, N. & Pratt, N. (2009). What kind of liberation? Women and the occupation of Iraq. Berkeley: California University Press.

Al-Ali, Z. (2014). The struggle for Iraq’s future. How corruption, incompetence and sectarianism have undermined democracy. New Haven: Yale University Press.

Al-Dulaimi, N. (1952). المرأة العراقیة [The Iraqi woman]. Baghdad.

Ali, Z.. (2016). Young grassroots activism on the rise in Iraq. Voices from Baghdad and Najaf. In Open Democracy. www.opendemocracy.net/north-africa-west-asia/zahra-ali/young-grassroots-activism-on-rise-in-iraq-voices-from-baghdad-and-najaf. Accessed 10 July 2018.

Ali, Z. (2017). The fragmentation of gender in post-invasion Iraq. In A. Ghazal & J. Hanssen (Eds.), The Oxford handbook of contemporary Middle-Eastern and North African history. Oxford Handbooks Online.

Ali, Z. (2018). Women and gender in Iraq. Between nation-building and fragmentation. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press.

Al-Jawaheri, Y. H. (2008). Women in Iraq. The gender impact of international sanctions. New York: I.B. Tauris.

Anderson, J.N.D. (1963). Changes in the Law of Personal Status in Iraq. International and Comparative Law Quarterly 12(3), 1026–1031.

Arato, A. (2009). Constitution making under occupation. The politics of imposed revolution in Iraq. New York: Columbia University Press.

Bashkin, O. (2009). The other Iraq. Pluralism and culture in Hashemite Iraq. Stanford: Stanford University Press.

Charrad, M. M. (2001). States and women’s rights. The making of postcolonial Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco. Berkeley: University of California Press.

Charrad, M. M. (2011). Gender in the Middle East. Islam, state, agency. Annual Review of Sociology, 37, 417–437.

Da’ud al-Shaikh, S. (1958). Awwal al-Tariq Ila al-Nahda al-Niswiyya fi al-‘Iraq. Baghdad: Matba’a al-Rabita.

Damluji, M. (2010). Securing democracy in Iraq. Sectarian politics and segregation in Baghdad, 2003–2007. Traditional Dwellings and Settlements Review, 21(2), 71–87. Da’ud, Sabiha al-Shaikh. اول الطریق الى النھضة النسویة في العراق [The rst steps toward women’s awakening in Iraq], Baghdad 1958.

Davis, E. (2005). Memories of state. Politics, history and collective identity in modern Iraq. California: University of California Press.

Dawisha, A. (2009). Iraq. A political history from independence to occupation. Princeton: Princeton University Press.

Dodge, T. (2003). Inventing Iraq: The failure of nation building and a history denied. New York: Columbia University Press.

Dodge, T. (2005). Iraq’s future. The aftermath of regime change. Abingdon: Routledge.

Efrati, N. (1999). Negotiating rights in Iraq. Women and the personal status law. Middle East Journal, 59(4), 575–595.

Efrati, N. (2005). Negotiating rights in Iraq: Women and the Personal Statuts Law, Middle East Journal, 59(4), 575–95.

Efrati, N. (2008). Competing narratives. Histories of the women’s movement in Iraq, 1910–1958. International Journal of Middle East Studies, 40(3), 445–466.

Efrati, N. (2012). Women in Iraq. Past meets present. New York: Columbia University Press.

Farouk-Sluglett, M. (1993). Liberation or repression? Pan-Arab nationalism and the women’s movement in Iraq. In D. Hopwood, H. Ishow, & T. Koszinowski (Eds.), Iraq: Power and society. Oxford: Ithaca Press.

Farouk-Sluglett, M. & Sluglett, P. (1987). Iraq since 1958. From Revolution to Dictatorship. London/New York: I.B. Tauris.

Farouk-Sluglett, M. & Sluglett, P. (1991). The Historiography in Modern Iraq. The American Historical Review, 96(5), 1408–1421.

Gordon, J. (2010). Invisible War, the United States and the Iraq Sanctions. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.

Haddad, F. (2010). Sectarian relations in Arab Iraq. Competing mythologies of history, people and state. Ph.D. thesis, University of Exeter, Arab and Islamic Studies.

Haddad, F. (2014). A sectarian awakening. Reinventing Sunni identity in Iraq after 2003. Current Trends in Islamist Ideology, 17, 145–176. 14.

Ismael, J. S., & Ismael, S. T. (2000). Gender and state in Iraq. In S. Joseph (Ed.), Gender and citizenship in the Middle East. Syracuse: Syracuse University Press.

Ismael, J. S., & Ismael, S. T. (2007). Iraqi women under occupation: From tribalism to neo-feudalism. International Journal of Contemporary Iraqi Studies, 1(2), 247–268.

Ismael, J. S., & Ismael, S. T. (2008). Living through war, sanctions and occupation. The voices of Iraqi women. International Journal of Contemporary Iraqi Studies, 2(3), 409–424.

Ismael, T. Y., & Ismael, J. S. (2015). Iraq in the twenty-first century. Regime change and the making of a failed state. London: Routledge.

Joseph, S. (1991). Elite strategies for state building. Women, family, religion and the state in Iraq and Lebanon. In D. Kandiyoti (Ed.), Women, Islam, and the state (pp. 176–200). London: MacMillan.

Kandiyoti, D. (2007). Between the hammer and the anvil. Post-conict reconstruction, Islam and women’s rights. Third World Quarterly, 28(3), 503–517.

Khoury, D. R. (2012). The 1991 Intifada in three keys: Writing the history of violence. In J. Tejel, P. Sluglett, R. Bocco, & H. Bozarslan (Eds.), Writing the modern history of Iraq. Historiographical and political challenges (pp. 245–267). London: World Scientific Publishing.

Khoury, D. R. (2013). Iraq in wartime. Soldiering, martyrdom, and remembrance. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press.

Luizard, P.-J. (1991). La formation de l’Irak contemporain, Le rôle politique des ulémas chiites à la fin de la domination ottomane et au moment de la création de l’Etat irakien. Paris: CNRS.

Luizard, P.-J. (Ed.). (2006). Le choc colonial et l’islam, Les politiques religieuses des puissances coloniales en terres d’islam. Paris: La Découverte.

Pieri, C.. (2014). Can T-wall murals really beautify the fragmented Baghdad? Jadaliyya. 18 May, www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/17704/can-t-wall-murals-really-beautify-the-fragmented-b. Accessed 10 Jul 2018.

Rohde, A. (2010). Gender policies in Ba’athist Iraq. In State-society relations in Ba’thist Iraq (pp. 75–118). London: Routledge.
